In mathlib4, there is currently no ProofTheory, so I am considering adding it (also I want to include the proof of the first incompleteness theorem that I have proved in lean4-logic). However, I'm unsure how to formalize the concept of proof of first-order logic. There are several approaches:

  1. Tait-style Sequent Calculus: This is what I adopted in lean4-logic. Due to its simplicity in rules, theorems like the cut elimination and completeness can be relatively easily proven. However, it is not compatible with the current definition of formula in mathlib.

  2. Hilbert-style Proof System : This approach is adopted in flypitch. I think it aligns well with the current ModelTheory, but it cannot formalize crucial results in proof theory, such as cut elimination.

  3. Gentzen-style Sequent Calculus: This is a compromise between the previous two, but I am not aware of any projects use this, this formalization would be challenging.

Additionally, there is room for choice in how to prove the completeness theorem. I used proof search on Tait calculus, while flypitch adopts Henkin's proof. Which method should I choose?

In an ideal world, we'd have all of these and have proofs that they all are equivalent. And I don't see a particular reason that one formalism is the right one superseding the rest. So for the purposes of contributing to Mathlib I'm going to argue for starting with whichever makes the current contribution work best, and if it proves hard to do other work in it, prove an explicit equivalence between the forms.
Thanks. I would like to start with Tait calculation as a basis and work independently of ModelTheory.
Is this work in progress @Palalansoukî ? I would love to see it and understand it!

I am not working on the porting right now as I am currently busy formalizing Godel's second incompleteness theorem, but the project itself is proceeding (https://github.com/iehality/lean4-logic, #11142), although #11142 will need to be rewritten as there have been major changes in the fundamentals.

Also I am working with @Hunter Monroe on the porting. The rewrite of #11142 to match the current version has not yet been done.

Yes. Porting here refers to porting lean4-logic into mathlib.

Recovering this thread: I am formalizing Gentzen-style calculus now :) The most important thing for me is implementing useful custom syntax, so that we can be sure the proofs are done inside of the gentzen calculus and not inside lean; for that we need a couple custom tactics to handle List properties well without having to use 'rw List.property', 'simp' etc. - because there will be no such tactics in gentzen
